summary: This is a letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York to Judge Alison J. Nathan, outlining the government's plan to obtain and review investigative files from other agencies, particularly those related to the prior Florida investigation into Jeffrey Epstein, for potential disclosure in the Ghislaine Maxwell case. It details the scope of discovery produced and the legal framework governing disclosure obligations. This is a government filing from the Southern District of New York in the Ghislaine Maxwell case, outlining the prosecution's approach to reviewing materials from prior investigations (specifically the USAO-SDFL Florida investigation and USAO-SDGA's involvement in CVRA civil litigation) for potential Giglio and 3500 material. It details the scope of the email review and affirms the prosecution team's commitment to disclosure obligations.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: Presiding judge in the case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell; recipient of this government letter outlining discovery plans.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Subject of the prior Florida investigation (2005-2010) for sexual abuse of minors; his case is referenced as separate from the current Maxwell prosecution.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The subject of the current prosecution; the government is reviewing materials from other investigations for information about her.

persons.name: Alfredo Rodriguez
persons.context: An employee of Jeffrey Epstein who was prosecuted by the FBI Florida Office for obstruction of justice; the Prosecution Team has received some files from that case.

persons.name: Attorney-1
persons.context: A former prosecutor from the Southern District of Florida whose emails are being reviewed by the current prosecution for potential communications with or regarding witnesses relevant to the Ghislaine Maxwell case.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: The signatory of the court filing, submitting it on behalf of the government.

connections.description: Maxwell is the defendant in the current case arising from an investigation into Epstein's activities; the document references the separate Florida investigation of Epstein.
Rodriguez is identified as an employee of Epstein who was prosecuted for obstruction of justice related to the Florida investigation.
Attorney-1 was the primary line Assistant U.S. Attorney who worked on the federal Florida Investigation into Epstein.
Attorney-1 was the primary prosecutor on a prior investigation that involved conduct similar to that in the Maxwell case, making their communications a subject of review.
Strauss, as Acting U.S. Attorney, is leading the prosecution team bringing the case against Maxwell.

events.title: Initial Conference
events.description: Court held initial conference in the Ghislaine Maxwell case and inquired about the government's plan to review other investigative files for disclosures.

events.title: Start of Florida Investigation
events.description: The Palm Beach Police Department opened its investigation into Jeffrey Epstein for sexual abuse of minors.

events.title: Federal Florida Investigation
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida and the FBI's Palm Beach office conducted a federal investigation into Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: SDNY Investigation Opened
events.description: The investigation conducted by USAO-SDNY, FBI New York, and NYPD that led to the charges against Ghislaine Maxwell was opened.

events.title: Electronic Discovery Deadline
events.description: The government expects to meet this deadline for the completion of electronic discovery productions in the Maxwell case.

events.title: USAO-SDGA Designated for CVRA Litigation
events.description: Attorneys from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Georgia were designated to represent the U.S. in CVRA civil litigation brought by Epstein victims, after the Southern District of Florida was recused.

events.title: Government Filing on Disclosure Obligations
events.description: The prosecution files a detailed letter with the court outlining its plans to review materials from prior investigations for potential disclosure in the Ghislaine Maxwell case.

locations: Silvio J. Mollo Building, One Saint Andrew's Plaza, New York, New York 10007
United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: The government has produced approximately 328,863 pages of discovery to Ghislaine Maxwell's defense, including photos, search warrants, financial records, and phone records.
The prosecution team is separate from the prior Florida investigation team, and under legal precedent, is not automatically obligated to review those files, but is doing so voluntarily.

The government has obtained or is in the process of obtaining files from six sources related to the Florida investigation: Palm Beach Police Department, Palm Beach State's Attorney's Office, FBI Florida Office, USAO-Southern District of Florida, and DOJ OPR emails.
The FBI Florida Office's case file, which the prosecution team already possesses, is believed to contain substantially all prior witness statements from the Florida investigation.
The Department of Justice's Office of Professional Responsibility (OPR) conducted an unrelated investigation into the resolution of the Florida case and gathered internal DOJ emails.

The government is reviewing emails of 'Attorney-1', the primary prosecutor from the prior Southern District of Florida (SDFL) Epstein investigation, for potential witness communications relevant to the Ghislaine Maxwell case.
The prosecution asserts there is no substantial overlap of victims or witnesses between the prior SDFL investigation and the current Maxwell prosecution.

The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Georgia (SDGA) was involved in representing the U.S. in CVRA civil litigation after the SDFL was recused, and the prosecution will contact them for any relevant witness communications or information on Maxwell.
The filing explicitly states that none of the other offices or agencies (SDFL, SDGA, OPR) played any role in investigating, charging, or presenting the current Maxwell case to the grand jury.
